Award.AwardTitle: RUI, SBP, Collaborative Research: Exploring the unique effects of shared past adversity for enhancing social connection and identify-safety in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Representation matters for promoting students’ interest and belonging in STEM. Research has not clearly identified who counts as representation for different groups of students? Which scientists act as role models to spark students’ engagement with STEM? For a scientist to be a role model, it is important that students feel similar to that scientist, and students often feel similar to a person who has a matching identity, such as a female scientist for female students or a Black scientist for Black students. It is less clear, however, who would be a role model for Black female students who have multiple important identities (i.e. both Black, female, and STEM). This research will test the prediction that Black female students feel similar to scientists when they believe the scientist has had comparable experiences with discrimination (i.e., has faced similar types of racism or sexism). This is a critical question to explore because Black women are severely underrepresented in STEM, and as a result, the current work aims to provide practical techniques for recruiting and retaining Black women in these fields. This research tests how and when representation matters for Black women.<br/><br/>This research will test how the context influences identification with various role-model types. This research contrasts whether having similar encounters with bias due to one’s identity (i.e., race or gender) versus having a common struggle is better for fostering feelings of similarity with a potential role model. The research tests the hypothesis that race tends to be more salient than gender in most situations for Black women. Thus, Black women are more likely to feel similar to a scientist matching their race than their gender because of the continuing racism permeating US society. That is, the primary hypothesis is that Black women will believe that a Black scientist has had more similar experiences with discrimination when compared to a White female scientist. However, context matters. In STEM fields where women are particularly under-represented, White female scientists may act as role models for Black women majors. Finally, we will investigate when and why Black female students might identify with a Latino male scientist who also faces race-based discrimination. All three studies will examine important outcomes related to feeling similar to the scientist including belonging, confidence, interest, and engagement in STEM. This research has direct applications to broadening participation for students in STEM fields and to models of identity.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Representation matters for promoting students’ belonging within STEM. Indeed, within psychology, multiple studies have demonstrated that role models are critical for inspiring women’s interest and persistence across many STEM fields. One way that female students can learn about potential role models is in their classes. Specifically, professors and instructors can act as role models themselves and encourage feelings of belonging. However, not all instructors will function as role models. Instructors are most likely to promote belonging when they are part of students’ ingroup, and students feel similar to the instructor. As a result, typically, female instructors are more likely than male instructors to foster feelings of belonging and inclusion among female students. However, an important question for role model and psychological research broadly is – who acts as the most beneficial role model among women with multiple identities (i.e., Black women)? 

Addressing this question across 6 studies, this research recognized the importance of identity-based adversity for fostering connections and felt similarity with STEM classroom instructors. Given the prevalence of racism within U.S. society, race-based discrimination tends to be chronically salient for Black women, more so than gender-based discrimination. Thus, across all of our studies, we consistently found that U.S. Black female students believed that a Black female or male STEM instructor had more similar experiences bias than a White female STEM professor. Consequently, students felt more similar to Black instructors than a White female instructor, and higher felt similarity ultimately related to more belonging in the professor’s class. We replicated this finding with hypothetical professors (i.e., in carefully controlled experiments), and when having students reflect on their current instructors and real classroom environments. 

In the current research, we also acknowledged that context matters and examined whether this pattern of results would change in situations where women are underrepresented and face sexism. We did find that Black women were sensitive to environments with sexism. That is, when Black female students were in these situations (i.e., in a major with documented gender bias or an apparent gender disparity), they reported that sexism was more of an issue than racism in this specific context (i.e., in the major). At the same time, Black female students still perceived more racism in society broadly than sexism. Highlighting the significance of shared societal-level adversity, regardless of whether gender bias was prevalent in a specific situation, Black female students felt more similar to a Black male instructor than a White female instructor. However, making Black women aware of pervasive and societal sexism in STEM did help encourage their identification with a White female instructor. 

The findings from this project provide strong evidence that societal identity-based adversity is a powerful mechanism for promoting connections with specific exemplars and instructors. By understanding the importance of shared identity-based adversity, we can develop a theoretical model that predicts who acts as role models for women with multiple marginalized identities, filling a critical gap with the psychological literature. Moreover, psychological closeness is crucial for a variety of processes beyond issues of role models and belonging. Thus, this theoretical model is relevant to and can speak to many research areas in psychology (e.g., persuasion, person perception, intergroup, and intragroup relations).  

The research also has important implications for broadening participation in STEM and recruiting and retaining Black women in these fields. Feeling a sense of belonging in an environment is a critical predictor of interest and persistence in that field. Thus, it is practically important to understand when and why Black women experience belonging and inclusion in their classes. The current research demonstrates how instructors themselves can foster belonging in their STEM courses. Moreover, these studies highlight the importance of ensuring that Black female students learn about Black scientists in their STEM courses (e.g., through readings, lectures, and in-class videos).
